mytokens.name: offtoseethe_exit
mytokens.description: We're Off to See the... Objective Completed: End the run by hitting the exit (marked in yellow)..

metadata.body: Many people don't know this, but most of us elves have multiple jobs here in the North Pole. In addition to working in Santa's workshop, I also work as a help desk support associate for the North Pole Elf Database site. I answer password reset requests, mostly from other elves.
metadata.name: Wunorse Openslae
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: One time, I got a weird email with a JavaScript alert and my account got hacked. Fortunately, Alabaster was able to add some filtering on the system to prevent that from happening again. I sure hope he tested his changes against the common evasion techniques discussed on the [XSS filter evasion cheat sheet](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_Filter_Evasion_Cheat_Sheet).
metadata.name: Wunorse Openslae
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: It's never a good idea to come up with your own encryption scheme with cookies. Alabaster told me he uses JWT tokens because they are super secure as long as you use a long and complex key. Otherwise, they could be cracked and recreated using any old framework like [pyjwt](https://github.com/jpadilla/pyjwt) to forge a key.
metadata.name: Wunorse Openslae
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.body: The interface we use lets us query our directory database with all the employee information. Per Santa's request, Alabaster restricted the search results to just the elves and reindeer. Hopefully, he secured that too. I found an article recently talking about [injection against similar databases](https://pen-testing.sans.org/blog/2017/11/27/understanding-and-exploiting-web-based-ldap).
metadata.name: Wunorse Openslae
metadata.title: Hint 4

metadata.text: Congratulations 100% completion of *We're Off to See the*!
metadata.tweet: I finished 100% of We're Off to See the!

mytokens.name: home_exit
mytokens.description: There's Snow Place Like Home Objective Completed: End the run by hitting the exit (marked in yellow)..

metadata.body: I'm so excited for the new email system that Alabaster Snowball set up for us. He spent a lot of time working on it. Should make it very easy for us to share cookie recipes. I just hope that he cleared up all his dev files. I know he was working on keeping the dev files from search engine indexers.
metadata.name: Pepper Minstix
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: The new email system's authentication should be impenetrable. Alabaster was telling me that he came up with his own encryption scheme using AES256, so you know it's secure.
metadata.name: Pepper Minstix
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: AES256? Honestly, I don't know much about it, but Alabaster explained the basic idea and it sounded easy. During decryption, the first 16 bytes are removed and used as the initialization vector or "IV." Then the IV + the secret key are used with AES256 to decrypt the remaining bytes of the encrypted string.
metadata.name: Pepper Minstix
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.body: Hmmm. That's a good question, I'm not sure what would happen if the encrypted string was only 16 bytes long.
metadata.name: Pepper Minstix
metadata.title: Hint 4

metadata.body: Every year when Santa gets back from delivering presents to the good girls and boys, he tells us stories about all the cookies he receives. I love everything about cookies! Cooking them, eating them, editing them, decorating them, you name it!
metadata.name: Pepper Minstix
metadata.title: Hint 5

metadata.text: Congratulations on making it to the exit of *There's Snow Place Like Home*! Check out your [stocking page](/stocking) for some hints!
metadata.tweet: I completed There's Snow Place Like Home!

mytokens.name: bounce_exit
mytokens.description: Bumbles Bounce Objective Completed: End the run by hitting the exit (marked in yellow)..

metadata.body: I have a very important job at the North Pole: GDPR compliance officer. Mostly I handle data privacy requests relating to Santa's naughty and nice list. I maintain the documents for compliance on the North Pole file store server.
metadata.name: Minty Candycane
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: The North Pole Police Department works closely with Santa on the naughty and nice list infractions. Mild naughty events are "1 coal" infractions, but can reach as high as "5 coal" level.
metadata.name: Minty Candycane
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: I'm still a little shaken up from when I had to call them in the other day. Two elves started fighting, pulling hair, and throwing rocks. There was even a super atomic wedgie involved! Later we were told that they were Munchkin Moles, though I'm still not sure I can believe that.
metadata.name: Minty Candycane
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.body: Unrelated, but: have you had the pleasure of working with JSON before? It's an easy way to programmatically send data back and forth over a network. There are simple JSON import/export features for almost every programming language!
metadata.name: Minty Candycane
metadata.title: Hint 4

metadata.body: One of the conveniences of working with JSON is that you can edit the data files easily with any text editor. There are lots of online services to convert JSON to other formats too, such as CSV data. Sometimes the JSON files need a little coaxing to get the data in the right format for conversion, though.
metadata.name: Minty Candycane
metadata.title: Hint 5

messages.msg: You've done it! You found out who was throwing the giant snowballs! It was the Abominable Snow Monster. We should have known. Thank you for your great work!
But, you know, he doesn't seem quite himself. Look into his eyes. It almost looks like he has been hypnotized. Something's not right with him.
In fact, he seems to be under someone else's control. We've got to find out who is pulling his strings, or else the real villain will remain on the loose and will likely strike again.
It means, buckle your seatbelt, dear player, because the North Pole is going bye-bye

metadata.text: Congratulations on making it to the exit of *Bumbles Bounce*! Check out your [stocking page](/stocking) for some hints!
metadata.tweet: I completed Bumbles Bounce!

metadata.message: Conversation with Glinda, the Good Witch

messages.msg: It's me, Glinda the Good Witch of Oz! You found me and ruined my genius plan!

You see, I cast a magic spell on the Abominable Snow Monster to make him throw all the snowballs at the North Pole. Why? Because I knew a giant snowball fight would stir up hostilities between the Elves and the Munchkins, resulting in all-out WAR between Oz and the North Pole. I was going to sell my magic and spells to both sides. War profiteering would mean GREAT business for me.
But, alas, you and your sleuthing foiled my venture. And I would have gotten away with it too, if it weren't for you meddling kids!

metadata.text: Congratulations on unlocking the final cutscene and finding out who did it!!
metadata.tweet: I unlocked the final cutscene!

mytokens.name: cliffs_exit
mytokens.description: Winconceivable: The Cliffs of Winsanity  Objective Completed: End the run by hitting the exit (marked in yellow)..

metadata.body: We're excited to debut the new Letters to Santa site this year. Alabaster worked hard on that project for over a year. I got to work with the development version of the site early on in the project lifecycle.
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: Near the end of the development we had to rush a few things to get the new site moved to production. Some development content on the letter page should probably have been removed, but ended up marked as hidden to avoid added change control paperwork.
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: Alabaster's primary backend experience is with Apache Struts. I love Apache and have a local instance set up on my home computer with a web shell. Web shells are great as a backdoor for me to access my system remotely.  I just choose a really long complex file name so that no one else knows how to access it.
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.body: A simple web shell is to create a PHP file in the web root with `" . shell_exec($_GET['e']) . ""; ?>`. Then, I visit the URL with my commands. For example, *http://server/complexFileName.php?e=ls*.
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 4

metadata.body: There are lots of different web shell tools available. [You can get a simple PHP web shell that is easy to use here](https://gist.github.com/joswr1ght/22f40787de19d80d110b37fb79ac3985).
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 5

metadata.body: That business with Equal-Facts Inc was really unfortunate. I understand there are a lot of different exploits available for those vulnerable systems. Fortunately, Alabaster said he tested for CVE-2017-5638 and it was NOT vulnerable. Hope he checked the others too.
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 6

metadata.body: Apache Struts uses XML. I always had problems making proper XML formatting because of special characters. I either had to encode my data or escape the characters properly so the XML wouldn't break. I actually just checked and there are lots of different exploits out there for vulnerable systems. [Here is a useful article](https://pen-testing.sans.org/blog/2017/12/05/why-you-need-the-skills-to-tinker-with-publicly-released-exploit-code).
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 7

metadata.body: Pro developer tip: Sometimes developers hard code credentials into their development files. Never do this, or at least make sure you take them out before publishing them or putting them into production. You also should avoid reusing credentials for different services, even on the same system.
metadata.name: Sparkle Redberry
metadata.title: Hint 8

metadata.text: Congratulations on making it to the exit of *Winconceivable: The Cliffs of Winsanity*! Check out your [stocking page](/stocking) for some hints!
metadata.tweet: I completed Winconceivable: The Cliffs of Winsanity!

metadata.body: Nmap has default host discovery checks that may not discover all hosts.  To customize which ports Nmap looks for during host discovery, use `-PS` with a port number, such as `-PS123` to check TCP port 123 to determine if a host is up.
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: Alabaster likes to keep life simple. He chooses a strong password, and sticks with it.
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: The Letters to Santa server is limited in what commands are available. Fortunately, SSH has enough flexibility to make access through the Letters server a fruitcake-walk.
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.body: Have you used port forwarding with SSH before? It's pretty amazing! [Here is a quick guide](https://help.ubuntu.com/community/SSH/OpenSSH/PortForwarding).
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 4

metadata.body: Windows users can use SSH port forwarding too, using PuTTY! [Here is a quick guide for Windows users](https://blog.devolutions.net/2017/04/how-to-configure-an-ssh-tunnel-on-putty.html).
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 5

metadata.body: Sometimes it's better to use a Linux system as the SSH port forwarder, and interact with a Linux system from a Windows box. For example, running `ssh -L :445:SMBSERVERIP:445 username@sshserver` will allow you to access your Linux server's IP, which will forward directly to the SMB server over SSH.
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 6

metadata.body: Linux systems can also interact with a Windows server using the smbclient utility: `smbclient -L smbserverorforwarder -U username`.
metadata.name: Holly Evergreen
metadata.title: Hint 7

metadata.body: The Elf As A Service (EAAS) site is a new service we're experimenting with in the North Pole. Previously, if you needed a special engineer for toy production, you would have to write a memo and distribute it to several people for approval. All of that process is automated now, allowing production teams to request assistance through the EAAS site.
metadata.name: Sugarplum Mary
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: The EAAS site uses XML data to manage requests from other teams. There is a sample request layout available that you can download. Teams just customize the XML and submit!
metadata.name: Sugarplum Mary
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: I think some of the elves got a little lazy toward the go-live date for EAAS. The sample XML data doesn't even include a DTD reference.
metadata.name: Sugarplum Mary
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.body: XML processing can be complex. I saw an interesting article recently on the [dangers of external XML entities](https://pen-testing.sans.org/blog/2017/12/08/entity-inception-exploiting-iis-net-with-xxe-vulnerabilities).
metadata.name: Sugarplum Mary
metadata.title: Hint 4

metadata.text: Congratulations on making it to the exit of *I Don't Think We're In Kansas Anymore*! Check out your [stocking page](/stocking) for some hints!
metadata.tweet: I completed I Don't Think We're In Kansas Anymore!

metadata.body: I'm still a little angry with Alabaster for reprimanding me for a security violation. He still checks his email from the EMI system!
metadata.name: Shinny Upatree
metadata.title: Hint 1

metadata.body: He tells us not to install unnecessary software on systems, but he's running IIS with ASPX services on the EMI server, and Microsoft Office!
metadata.name: Shinny Upatree
metadata.title: Hint 2

metadata.body: Personally, I don't use Microsoft Word. I'll take vim and LaTeX any day. Word does have its advantages though, including some of the Dynamic Data Exchange features for transferring data between applications and obtaining data from external data sources, including executables.
metadata.name: Shinny Upatree
metadata.title: Hint 3

metadata.text: Congratulations on making it to the exit of *Oh Wait! Maybe we are...*! Check out your [stocking page](/stocking) for some hints!
metadata.tweet: I completed Oh Wait! Maybe we are...!
